This was the first time ever that I filled all the shaded and theme squares first. As a gay man living near the Theater District, it's possible I've seen Wicked (Broadway and movie) a few times.

I read *Wicked*, the novel by Gregory Maguire, shortly after it was released, in Jan. 1996, while I was on medical leave with a quite severe case of hepatitis A, and quite jaundiced. Somehow, the idea of a dermatologically challenged heroine appealed to me. "Well, cute bit of "revisionist" metafiction, but not much there--a one-trick pony." 

So I was surprised when that one-trick pony spawned several sequels, as well as similar "revisions" of Cinderella and Snow White, and of course, a Broadway musical (and subsequent movie). 

I have, subsequently, seen the musical, and have sung at least one of the songs, arranged for show-choir; and, glancing at but not solving the revealer, I realized why the circles were green, and could confidently enter E_L_P_H_A_B_A into them.

I think what bothers me about *Wicked*, in all its media incarnations, is that it's cluttered--it has talking animals, but also non-talking animals, and people; it has studies like magic, but also sciences like chemistry. C'mon, people, it's either one or the other--fantasy or realism. For all its faults, at least Harry Potter is consistent (at least within the wizarding world.); and there are no cars in Middle Earth.

Every inning after the 9th now starts with a baserunner on second base. This ensures the game won't go too long.

Though I am a lifelong baseball fan that is sick of MLB's attempts to make the game more accessible to a TikTok society, I feel its important that the NYT crossword at least stays up to date on the latest dumb rules.

Mixed feelings here.

On the one hand, great fill! A few personal favorites: TOAST, BOSSY, HOTWIRE. Also, from a mechanical standpoint, the theme was very nicely executed ‚Äî the answers form valid words as entered, and digital solvers get a fun little animation at the end.

On the other hand‚Ä¶personally, I have never seen Wicked, and I have no interest in changing that. In fact, after being force-fed marketing campaigns for the last few decades (first for Broadway productions, then traveling shows, and finally the recent movie), I find the whole ‚Äúbrand‚Äù incredibly annoying, as a forerunner to the current era of endless reboots/reimaginings (i.e. parasitizing the creative output from previous generations and piggybacking on already-familiar iconography and fictional worlds, rather than creating new ones).

Now, if I am solidly in the minority with the above view: ok! But I have to suspect I am far from alone in my feelings about Wicked‚Ä¶

GEEKOUT ALERT!

Over a decade ago I happened upon a movie on TV-"Til There Was You'. I don't remember liking it much, but there was one line of dialogue that caught my attention: "My name is Gawayne with a Ga."

I looked it up and sure enough the writer of the movie was Winnie Holzman who also wrote the book* for the musical Wicked.

I'm not sure I quoted the movie correctly. I had do some searching just to find the name of the character who probably spoke the line.

*Book refers to the dialogue and plot, not to be confused with the book Wicked that the musical was based on. To any parents thinking about giving that book to a Wicked-obsessed youngster, you might want to look it over first to see if you deem it appropriate. I thought it was a decent book, but it's also quite indecent.

***In the musical,  Galinda corrects someone, saying that her name is not Glinda but "Galinda with a Ga".

******* Although she later changes her name to Glinda.
Well, that‚Äôs one way to ruin Wicked üòÇ

Hi everyone!¬† Constructor here.¬† I was hesitant to comment because I don't want people to see that I'm reading these and be discouraged to comment negatively if that's how they're inclined!
Anyway, as many of you know, NYT typically changes about half of a puzzle's clues, which is roughly what they did here.¬† As always, I think most of their changes made the puzzle much better!¬† That said, a couple of notes you may find interesting:--I didn't expressly reference "Wicked" at all in my cluing, as I wanted to (a) accommodate solvers who knew nothing of it, and (b) have the circled letters be an easter egg for whose who did.¬† I just had the theme answers and circles in green, suggested the animation, and clued DEFYING GRAVITY as "Refusing to obey ... or what the circled letters are doing that makes the starred clues seem to not match their answers."--My clue for NOONEON was "Empty bags?".¬† I certainly *do* know my baseball, and although the final clue was not mine, I should have caught its inaccuracy when I reviewed the NYT proof.
Thanks to all of you for doing the puzzle and commenting -- I appreciate all of them, positive and negative!

And if you are a musical hater, just know that many people actually love them, or at least are familiar with the ones that are the top grossing film of a Broadway musical (not exactly niche!) and there's room for all kinds in this world of crossword puzzles.

It's interesting to me how many respondents are pooh-poohing the Wicked theme as if the film / Broadway show / book are not worth remembering. It was the top grossing musical film adaptation in history, and the Broadway show was the second-highest grossing in history. Surely it is a significant cultural phenomenon even if musicals aren't your thing. I personally don't like super-hero movies but I do know the basic idea of The Avengers even though I have seen none of the films. If a puzzle theme isn't part of your particular area of interest, why not take it as a challenge and maybe learn something new?

@Andrzej

Not a major musical theater fan, but do go occasionally, and I'm not trying to convince you of anything here, just relating my experiences.

The latest musical I saw was on Sunday, when we went to see "Ragtime," which was based on a story by E.L. Doctorow, weaving the lives of a rich suburban WASP family, a poor Harlem musician and his family, and an immigrant Jewish father and daughter together in the early 20th century.  It addressed the racism, anti-Semitism, xenophobia and classism of 100 years ago, and is still applicable today.  It was a nearly three-hour show, and worth every minute.  Some of the music bordered on operatic, but most of it, not so much.  And being a Broadway production, the performance was top notch. It was a very moving experience.

My earliest introduction to musical theater was in high school, when I participated in one ("The King and I"). (Minor non-singing role, of course!)

But the buzz that year among all the theater kids was the new "rock opera," "Jesus Christ Superstar."  Most of us got our first exposure to it from the cast album, available before the show was on Broadway.  We knew the entire show by heart (all singing, no spoken words).  And I think I can still sing practically any number from it even today.

Pretty odd for a kid just a few years removed from his bar mitzvah!

(Everything I know about the New Testament comes from that show.)

@Andrzej
Let me defend the musical.
Yes, there's plenty  of ersatz music but not every classical composer was Bach either. There are some beautiful motifs in Broadway that can compete with anything classical for complexity of construction and musicality.
As for bursting into song: I don't get how you defend opera,  which is far more artificial. At least, a musical's songs tend to be about subjects worth singing about, whereas in opera, some poor tenor has to /sing/, "Wait here, I will get us a carriage" because the spoken word is banned.
I'm not defending jukebox musicals here. They deserve all your complaints and more.  But Rodgers and Hart, Cole Porter, Frank Loesser, Sondheim, Bernstein -- in short, people who knew how to use music as an expression of character or mood, instead of just plopping it into the middle of a scene like a monstrous toad -- they wrote /great/ music as I see it.

@sonnel Rule 3.04 describes the size and shape of a catcher‚Äôs mitt. It says nothing about how the catcher may catch the pitched ball: 3.04 Catcher's Mitt The catcher may wear a leather mitt not more than thirty-eight inches in circumference, nor more than fifteen and one-half inches from top to bottom. Such limits shall include all lacing and any leather band or facing attached to the outer edge of the mitt. The space between the thumb section and the finger section of the mitt shall not exceed six inches at the top of the mitt and four inches at the base of the thumb crotch. The web shall measure not more than seven inches across the top or more than six inches from its top to the base of the thumb crotch. The web may be either a lacing, lacing through leather tunnels, or a center piece of leather which may be an extension of the palm, connected to the mitt with lacing and constructed so that it will not exceed any of the above mentioned measurements. https://www.umpirebible.com/OBR16/3.0.htm#304

For those of us who grew up loving the Wizard of Oz, Wicked provides the opportunity to recognize biases that were inherent in both the movie and in Baum's books, which we just unquestioningly accepted as children.
